bibl.title: Sanitation report by Walter Reed, May 31, 1887

div1.p: This report gives the sanitary conditions of the officers' quarters, yard, barracks, guardhouse, post hospital, and water at Fort Robinson. It also reports on rations and clothing.

div1.head: Sanitation report by Walter Reed, May 31, 1887
div1.opener:
3
May 1887.
Fort Robinson, Neb.
May 31st 1887.
To the,
Post Adjutant.
Sir.
div1.p:
In compliance with existing orders, I have the
honor to respectfully submit the following Sanitary Report
for the month ending May 31st 1887.

These are in fair sanitary condition. The set
confined by the Commanding Officer, to which attention
has heretofore been called, in the matter of defective
plumbing and drainage, is now being thoroughly over-
hauled, and it is believed that the present repairs will
put it in a safe condition.

The general police of yards connected with these
Quarters has been very good. Disinfection of vaults
along the line as well as throughout the garrison, at
least twice a week, with chloride of Lime and dry
earth, is respectfully recommended.

These have been fully described in former Sanitary
Reports as to lighting, ventilation etc.. with exception of
that occupied by ‘K’ Troop 9th Cav'y, the Buildings
are old, and dilapidated, miserably lighted, ventilated,
& unfit for the purpose of Barracks.

The recommendation made heretofore, concerning the
drainage of wash-room of the set occupied by “C” and “E”
Co's 8th Infty. is now being carried out in a very sat-
isfactory manner. Attention is respectfully called to
the necessity of better drainage of the bath & wash rooms
of the set now occupied by ‘C’ Troops 9th Cav'y.
In fair sanitary condition at present, surrounds

In good sanitary condition, except that waste-
paper from Bath-Tub. is at present obstructed. It is
respectfully requested that this may be attended to
AC
R
4
May 1887. Continued
as the Bath-Tub is in constant demand.

Sufficient in quantity, & properly cooked & served.
A few early vegetables have been obtained from the gardens.

The general police of the garrison has been
well performed.
div1.closer:
Very respectfully,
Your obt. Servant. Walter Reed,
Asst. Surg. U. S. A.
Post Surgeon. Copy forwarded to the Surgeon General U. S. A.
May 4th 1887.
